messageBody:
Alain RAVET wrote:

> Let me share my "experience" on - bad - web testing pain reaction :

Excellent, thank you, real experiences are what I'm looking for.

> THEN
> something happened with CVS, and some new code got overwritten by some
old code.
> ...
>
> BUT,
> I didn't notice, because it was used in some rare cases, in problems I
had solved a
> long time ago - a few weeks ago -.

We've had some experiences where web navigation or contents broke
as well, hence our desire to somehow bring out these problems before
the release gets too far down the pipe (i.e., as part of continuous
testing). For us, they are also relatively rare circumstances, and
that makes us wary of spending too much effort on this testing.

> NEXT WEEK, I think I'm goint go write a simple html parsing tool,
> that writes the java test code for me, so I can cut and paste it
> into my code, and adapt it.

I'm really hoping someone has done this already and we can buy or
download this tool!

Our QA manager was telling me today that she can record Silk Test
scripts in "no time," and then we have the web tests available. If
they are being recorded, then we don't have the test-first thing
going on, but she said they could at least script the manual test
prior to the iteration so we can use it to develop against. Like
any web tests, especially with JSPs that have to be generated by the
server, they take a bit too much time to run to be used as part of
the developers check-in routine. We probably want to run these as
part of a daily or twice daily automated build verification test.

Thanks for your comments,
-Paul Hodgetts
